ὅ L In the time ol Gaius (i. 128) condemnation to loss ol civitas took the lorm of aquae et ignis interdictio, which originally was merely a solemn confirmation os voluntary exile by which an accused civis with- drew himself from a criminal prosecution, and only subsequently came to be used, apart from that, as a form of punishment ; see Livy 2 5. 4 ς 26. 3, Cic. pro Caec. 35 34. Alter Gaius it became more usual to inflict loss of civitas by deportatio in insulam, a sentence of banishment sor lise to either an island or some confined space on the mainland, Dig. 32. ny Deportation of either child or father put an end to potestas, because (Tit. 9. 2 supr.) ‘ius potestatis proprium est civium Romanorum τ’ by losing his civitas the child lost his capacity os being in potestas, the father that os exercising it. ln case of restoration by imperial favour, as mentioned in the text, it seems that at first only such rights'were re· covered as were expressly specified (Vitellius ab exilio reversis iura libertorum concessit, Tac. Hist. 2. 92), and this was true in particular ol patria potestas: ‘in insulam filio deportato, hacque ratione vinculo paternae potestatis exempto, si postea ex indulgentia divi Alexandri, ut proponis, reditus in patrium solum praecedensque dignitas restituta sit, potestas tamen patria repetita non videtur’ Gordian in Cod p 51. 63 but this must probably be taken to have been overruled by Constantine in Cod. loc.cit.13, ‘in quaestione testamenti, quod deportati filius re- meante patre iecisset, remotis Ulpiani atque Pauli notis Papiniani placet valere sententiam, ut in patris filius sit potestate, cui dignitas ac bona restituta sunt’ It will be observed that here the termination oi the patria potestas was accompanied by capitis deminutio.
